definition: The process of entering a message (text) into a mathematical function/algorithm that returns a string of characters with a predetermined length. Cryptographic hashing algorithms prioritize one-wayness and collision resistance.
The property that makes it computationally infeasible (but not impossible) to reverse the hashing process. This processes is known as being pre-image resistant.
The property that makes it computationally infeasible to find a pair of messages (text) that produce the same hash output.

A unique, randomly generated string of characters that is appended to a password before hashing. Its primary purpose is to ensure that identical passwords produce different hash values. Defends against precomputed hash tables (rainbow tables).
A pre-computed table/database of hashed passwords, designed to assist malicious users by allows fast lookups of plaintext passwords corresponding to those hashes.

The number of times a hash function is applied to a given input. Increasing this count makes it more computationally intensive for malicious individuals to brute-force passwords. This process is also known as work factor.
